note.title: Overriding existing timers
note.para: The default set of &systemd; timers is stored in /usr/lib/systemd. If you create a timer with already existing names, the default unit file is not overwritten, but a new one is created in /etc/systemd/system/ that overrides the default unit file. To restore the timer to the default one, delete the timer unit file in /etc/systemd/system/.
If you try to create a timer that already exists in the /etc/systemd/system/ directory, the unit file will be overwritten, and the previous changes are lost.

topic.para: To create a &systemd; timer using &cockpit;, proceed as follows:

step.para: In the Timers tab, click Create timer.

listitem.para: The name of the timer that will be used in the unit name and in the service unit name as well. For example, specifying the name example will create the following unit files: /etc/systemd/system/example.timer and /etc/systemd/system/example.service.
You can provide a short description of the timer.
The command to be invoked when the timer is triggered.

The timer can be triggered each time you reboot your machine or at a specific time. For the After system boot option, you can define the delay of the service invocation. For the At specific time option, specify when the service should be invoked.
